action.primary: Promotes urination and unblocks painful urinary dysfunction

indications: Damp-Heat painful urinary dysfunction, especially Stone Lin or Blood Lin)
It is especially useful when these disorders are accompanied by constipation
Insufficient lactation, painful, swollen breasts and early-stage breast abscess

action.primary: Moistens the Intestines and unblocks the bowels

indications: Constipation due to Intestinal fluid insufficiency

contraindications: Use caution for those with loose stools due to Spleen Deficiency.

useCases: Edema with a sensation of heaviness and urinary difficulty.
Thin mucus accumulated in the epigastrium leading to nausea.
Dysuria due to Heat clumping in the Bladder with dribbling and rough urination.
Urinary tract stones from lower Jiao Damp-Heat.
Qi Stagnation causing insufficient lactation and swollen, painful breasts.
Constipation due to Intestinal fluid insufficiency.
Blood Stasis causing insufficient lactation and swollen, painful breasts.

notes: The above information relates to Fr. Malvae Dong Kui Guo. It is the primary herb used as Dong Kui Zi. Sm. Abutili Qing Mai Zi is bitter, neutral and enters the Bladder, Large Intestine and Liver. It clears Heat and facilitates urination to treat red and white dysenteric disorders and painful urinary dysfunction. It also resolves toxicity, reduces swellings, reduces superficial visual obstruction and clears the eyes to treat swollen abscesses and superficial visual obstruction. It is not used as often.

Both Dong Kui Guo and Talcum #{HuaShi} Hua Shi are slippery and unblock the orifices and are used for treating urinary difficulty with rasping pain in the urethra. Hua Shi is best at cooling Summerheat and removing Dampness and can be used topically for Damp-Heat sores, while Dong Gui Zi assists bowel movements and promotes lactation. It also reduces swelling.
For generalized dysuria, use this as a single herb remedy.
